article:
In archaeology a 'typology' is the result of the classification of things
according to their physical characteristics. The products of the classification,
i.e. the classes, are also called types. Most archaeological typologies organize
artifacts into types, but typologies of larger structures, including buildings,
field monuments, fortifications or roads, are equally possible. A typology helps
to manage a large mass of archaeological data. According to Doran and Hodson,
"this superficially straightforward task has proved one of the most time
consuming and contentious aspects of archaeological research".
